thread.title: BYU facing weak FCS opponent, but treating week like any other
thread.title_full: BYU facing weak FCS opponent, but treating week like any other | Deseret News

author: Jeff Call
title: BYU facing weak FCS opponent, but treating week like any other
text:
Cougar coaches and players insist they’re not taking anything for granted as they get ready to play Wagner.
Upcoming Games BYU Football BYU football stats & schedule Wagner @ BYU Lavell Edwards Stadium, Provo Oct. 24, 1:00 p.m. 2  Days   4  Hrs   32  Mins   47  Secs More Coverage BYU football: Offensive line backups filling in nicely BYU football: The Wagner Seahawks in 6 numbers PROVO — For the eighth time in coach Bronco Mendenhall’s 11-year tenure at BYU , the Cougars will face a team from the FCS, formerly known as Division I-AA.
Saturday, BYU hosts Wagner College from Staten Island, New York, and a member of the Northeastern Conference.
Mendenhall’s first victory as BYU’s head coach came against an FCS team, Eastern Illinois, in 2005. The Cougars are 7-0 against FCS opponents under Mendenhall, winning by an average score of 50-9.
Wagner is winless (0-6) this season, having lost by an average score of 33-13. The Seahawks lost 56-16 in their season opener at Rice.
But BYU coaches and players insist they’re not taking anything for granted this week.
“Maybe the fans and you all, the media, you look at records, but I don’t have that luxury because the bottom line is they have everything to gain and we’ve got everything to lose,” said wide receivers coach Guy Holliday. “So we’ve got to come out here and freakin’ play like we play every week, in a frenzy. And hopefully we won’t wait until the fourth quarter to play really well. That’s the key.”
What have coaches been emphasizing this week in practice?
“They’ve been emphasizing not treating it lightly and to use it to make ourselves better,” said linebacker Fred Warner. “We haven’t let off the gas at all. We’re treating it like a normal week.”
BYU has beaten FCS foes Eastern Washington, 42-7 (2007); Northern Iowa, 41-17 (2008); Idaho, 42-7 (2011); Weber State, 45-13 (2012); Idaho State, 59-13 (2013); and Savannah State, 64-0 (2014).
ROC’N’ROLL: BYU’s student section, Roar of Cougars (ROC), has been praised by players and coaches for their support and passion at LaVell Edwards Stadium this season.
“I’ll tell you what. I’ve been fortunate to have played and coached in some pretty big stadiums,” said offensive line coach Garett Tujague. “I would tell you it would be tough to find anybody better than our student section. The ROC gets after it. We feed off their energy and they feed off of ours. It’s special. I’m glad I don’t have to bring an offensive line unit in here and battle the other defense and the ROC. They do an amazing job. It’s a lot of fun and great energy at Edwards Stadium.”
ROCCO?: In the Wagner football release this week, coach Bronco Mendenhall is referred to as “Rocco” Mendenhall.
In the same release, Wagner devotes an entire page to BYU basketball assistant coach Quincy Lewis, who is a Wagner alum and Hall-of-Famer.
LESLIE BACK IN THE NFL: Former BYU wide receiver Jordan Leslie, who spent time with the Minnesota Vikings this season before being cut, signed with the Jacksonville Jaguars Wednesday. The Jaguars are traveling to London this weekend to face the Buffalo Bills.
EMAIL: jeffc@deseretnews.com
